bibl.note: Preparations for Thanksgiving at the house and the school - Program successful - Ten at Thanksgiving dinner - Miss Langmaid still with us

list.item: Preparations for Thanksgiving at the house and the school

p.del: Dearest Jane - The day before Thanksgiving and isn't it strange to be sitting here way off on the other side of the U.S. nibbling your grand old salted nuts & the delicious candies and you all getting ready for a real dinner for tomorrow - Who would have thought it a year ago? Pa wrote me that he expected to be home for Thanksgiving - so you will surely have a house full! The eats came this noon & just knew there would be salted nuts somehow - the first I've had for months - The card arrived at the same time so dear Jane your doubly - nay trebly sweet thoughts are much appreciated. It's 3:30 this dark & rainy p.m. - the house seems perfectly quiet & still - Evelyn Miss Langmaid & Emily have gone to the store to see about stuff for dinner tomorrow - Aunt Lizzie is I know not where - so am enjoying an unusual calm in my own room. A calm is enjoyable too for the program came off this p.m. & there was a grand cleaning-up afterwards. This was

followed on my part by my hustling up here - putting away my washing - hanging up my coats & gowns - getting into a wash dress - putting my little union suits to soak & then subsiding into the rocker by the open window. Such sudden changes of temperature! Yesterday a.m. we all ate breakfast on the back porch - no wraps either. What do you think of that?

div1.p: Please don't hustle yourself too much with the sweater - Isn't it an awfully hard color to work on very steadily? Know I shall be quite wild about it when it arrives.

I'm wondering about Christmas - Do you think I ought to send my relations anything - Aunt Lottie & the rest of them? It doesn't seem as though Thanksgiving were so near - and Christmas & New Orleans a month off! Baskets are so hard to get & such a demand for them too that I may not be able to get what I want for you and Nellie -
in time for Xmas - it's baskets of course & very different from those I've sent - Hope you liked the others as well as you expected.

Got just so far & then had to stop as my brain & hand did not seem to work together - Read a little while & then went to sleep - Spent the evening luxuriously looking over The Atlantic & my papers! This morning Emily & I cleaned as usual & fixed the table - 10 people - Mr. & Mrs. Huff & the two little girls - (Blanche & Mattie -) Aunt Lizzie & Mrs. Profitt - we three Pi Phis & Emily - Fixed a centerpiece of autumn leaves holly & sprigs of something they call "red bud" - in one of the baskets - Then had some tiny ones at each place filled with the salted nuts & a little place card - Took the initials of everyone - Evelyn's was "Entertains Brightly" - Evelyn's - "Ever Busy" - Mr. Huff's "A Hustler" - Mrs. H. - "Managers of Households" - etc. The table looked very nice with all our new dishes - stuffed chicken - sweet potatoes - gravy - rice - hot biscuits - jelly - pineapple salad - mince pie & coffee - It took us all morning to get things ready - the Huffs came at 11:30 just as I started for the mail - Was so pleased to get a letter from you Jane - & one from pa mailed at San Diego - I got another one from him yesterday which had been sent to Texas - the second that has gone there - Isn't it strange? Suppose he's home today! and you all had a big turkey dinner. Poor Jane - don't try to do too much for Mrs. Webster - We make a lot more of our guests than many people do - seems to me.

It's turned cold & cloudy & snow is being predicted by our weather prophet - Aunt Lizzie - The Huffs are gone & Mr. Huff has just returned with the Ford to take Evelyn & Miss Langmaid to Sevierville - They want to visit an industrial school in North Carolina getting back here about
Monday - Emily decided to ride down & back with Mr. Huff - but I'm pleased to be alone for awhile & get a few little things done. Mrs. Huff insisted on Emily & me going over for supper tonight & staying till tomorrow so guess that's the program - though I much prefer staying here & sleeping in my own little bed - Such is life in Gatlinburg! My hair needs washing - my stockings darning - & several garments mending - besides some school work to plan - letters to write etc. Next Friday there is to be a "box supper" at the school to raise money for books for our library & Evelyn has decided that she'd like my play given again that night too! Our program proved a great success - Monday night the stage & curtains were put up - Tuesday afternoon we went through the whole performance - Wednesday a.m. had a few classes & decorated
with greens & autumn leaves - having gone over the night before & planned it - the whole bunch of us! The oak trees are wonderful now - the maples & gums being practically bare - Our performance began about one - The stage was across the front of my room taking a little more than half - & the panel on the side was let down - the other raised giving entrance & exit & the extra space filled in by the piano - big screen & greens - First my room & Abbie's were grouped on the stage & sang a Thanksgiving song - then Emily's little youngsters sang too - next Abbie's class had a little performance about the months with a lot of singing etc lasting a good twenty minutes - Some of the older girls sang a song - then Emily's youngsters gave theirs - meanwhile I was fussing around in the sewing room pinning on collars & cuffs - painting the Indian etc. etc.
Mr. Cresswell blacked very wonderful mustaches - side burns & beards on the boys' faces - I made three big Puritan hats & they looked like the real thing too - thanks to my lessons in millinery - It was a job blackening them however.

There were seven scenes - & all went very well too - Estel made a very nice John Alden - big white collar & cuffs over his dark blue suit - big wide ribbon round his waist - bows on his shoes & at his knees - Puritan hat & Emily's blue cape for outdoor scene - Tom made a splendid captain - had a real helmet - sword - belt of cartridges & powder horn big boots & - stamped around & warmed up to the part generally - Cora was very pretty in her two spinning scenes - Had the whole class on the stage for the wedding scene & wound up by with a Thanksgiving song. Several have said it was the best program ever given - Evelyn told me that plays had been attempted here before but that they never went off well as this one did - which pleased me.

p.del: If none of you are going to give presents to each other - please don't send me any! Everything is so strange - feel as though it the time next any idea what I'll do or where I'll go when April comes!

Had a card from Uncle Art thanking me for the basket & saying that they had sold the old homestead at last & were going to the Evanston Hotel - a very new & swell place - also very expensive. Aunt Lottie was keen to get there when I saw her last summer - so guess she's happy now.
Well dearest family must cease for this time - Am so glad Arthur & Nell are leaving that house - never cared for it - Give my fond love to the girls & to Mrs. Webster too.
With loads & loads to you & pa -
